page.title: 01GEOGRAPHY OF SESSAY
page.content:
This section lies in the southern part of the Vale of Mowbray which in its turn is part of the{PLAIN or VALE OF {YORK.}After the Ice Age it was under water from melting glaciers hence the deposits of sand over clay and shale. This eventually drained away leaving the ground mainly 100 feet above sea level and still inclined to flood. In the past this was forest and bog.
{DRAINAGE}is still a problem and though very good farmland any part left uncultivated would rapidly revert to hawthorn dogrose and elder; eventually to forest trees: oak ash sycamore field maple and birch. All of these grow freely from seed. Drainage is from field-drains to the becks and then to the River Swale.
